contentrichtext.text: {{for|F-spaces in general topology|sub-Stonean space}} In [[functional analysis]], an '''F-space''' is a [[vector space]] ''V'' over the [[real number|real]] or [[complex number|complex]] numbers together with a [[metric (mathematics)|metric]] ''d'' : ''V'' × ''V'' → '''R''' so that # Scalar multiplication in ''V'' is [[continuous function#Continuous functions between metric spaces|continuous]] with respect to ''d'' and the standard metric on '''R''' or '''C'''. # Addition in ''V'' is continuous with respect to ''d''. # The metric is [[translation-invariant metric|translation-invariant]]; i.e., ''d''(''x'' + ''a'', ''y'' + ''a'') = ''d''(''x'', ''y'') for all ''x'', ''y'' and ''a'' in ''V'' # The metric space (''V'', ''d'') is [[completeness (topology)|complete]] Some authors call these spaces ''[[Fréchet space]]s'', but usually the term is reserved for [[locally convex]] F-spaces. The metric may or may not necessarily be part of the structure on an F-space; many authors only require that such a space be [[metrizable]] in a manner that satisfies the above properties. == Examples == Clearly, all [[Banach space]]s and [[Fréchet space]]s are F-spaces. In particular, a Banach space is an F-space with an additional requirement that {{nowrap|''d''(''αx'', 0) {{=}} {{!}}α{{!}}⋅''d''(''x'', 0)}}.<ref>Dunford N., Schwartz J.T. (1958). Linear operators. Part I: general theory. Interscience publishers, inc., New York. p. 59</ref> The [[Lp space|L<sup>p</sup> spaces]] are F-spaces for all {{nowrap|p > 0}} and for {{nowrap|p ≥ 1}} they are locally convex and thus Fréchet spaces and even Banach spaces. === Example 1 === <math>\scriptstyle L^\frac{1}{2}[0,\, 1]</math> is a F-space. It admits no continuous seminorms and no continuous linear functionals — it has trivial [[dual space]]. === Example 2 === Let <math>\scriptstyle W_p(\mathbb{D})</math> be the space of all complex valued [[Taylor series]] :<math>f(z)=\sum_{n \geq 0}a_n z^n</math> on the unit disc <math>\scriptstyle \mathbb{D}</math> such that :<math>\sum_{n}|a_n|^p < \infty</math> then (for {{nowrap|0 < p < 1}}) <math>\scriptstyle W_p(\mathbb{D})</math> are F-spaces under the [[p-norm]]: :<math>\|f\|_p= \sum_{n}|a_n|^p \qquad (0 < p < 1)</math> In fact, <math>\scriptstyle W_p</math> is a [[quasi-Banach algebra]]. Moreover, for any <math>\scriptstyle \zeta</math> with <math>\scriptstyle |\zeta| \;\leq\; 1</math> the map <math>\scriptstyle f \,\mapsto\, f(\zeta)</math> is a bounded linear (multiplicative functional) on <math>\scriptstyle W_p(\mathbb{D})</math>. == References == {{reflist}} * {{citation|first=Walter|last=Rudin|authorlink=Walter Rudin|title=Real & Complex Analysis|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=1966|isbn=0-07-054234-1}} [[Category:Functional analysis]] [[Category:Topological vector spaces]] [[Category:F-spaces]] [[pl:Przestrzeń Frécheta (analiza funkcjonalna)]]
